summary.overview:
## Back to Eden Garden for 2 Families (7 people)

This garden uses the **pure Back to Eden** method - quality compost/soil topped with deep wood chip mulch. This means significantly less watering, no tilling, and improving soil over time. The wood chip mulch suppresses weeds, retains moisture, and feeds the soil as it decomposes.

### Philosophy
- **Low water**: After establishment, the deep mulch means you may only need to water during extended dry spells
- **No-till**: Never disturb the soil layers - just add more compost and mulch on top each year
- **Feed the soil**: The decomposing wood chips feed soil biology continuously

### What to Expect Year 1
Year 1 is the hardest - you're building infrastructure and the soil ecosystem is establishing. Expect:
- Initial labor for bed construction and filling
- Learning curve with pest management
- Some settling of soil/mulch layers

### Years 2+
The garden gets **easier every year** as:
- Soil biology establishes
- Wood chips break down into rich compost
- You learn your microclimates
- Perennials mature and produce more

water_requirements.notes: Back to Eden method dramatically reduces watering. The deep wood chip mulch prevents evaporation and builds water-retaining organic matter in the soil. After establishment (year 2+), you may only need supplemental water during droughts. Drip irrigation with timer handles most needs automatically.

tips: **Morning harvest**: Pick vegetables in the morning when sugar content is highest
**Succession plant**: Don't plant all lettuce at once - stagger every 2-3 weeks
**Mulch heavily**: 4-6 inches of wood chips. If you see bare soil, add more
**Never till**: The soil ecosystem takes years to build. Adding amendments? Top-dress only
**Pest patrol**: Walk the garden daily. Catch problems early. Hand-pick hornworms and beetles
**Feed the soil, not the plants**: Add compost in spring, let soil biology do the rest
**Keep paths clear**: Wood chip paths need refreshing yearly. They're also growing medium!
**Rotate nightshades**: Tomatoes, peppers, eggplant, potatoes share diseases. 3-year rotation minimum
**Plant garlic in fall**: October/November planting = bigger bulbs next July
**Don't rush spring**: Zone 6b last frost is mid-May. Patience prevents replanting
**Take notes**: What worked? What didn't? Your garden journal is your best tool

growing_method.notes: Pure Back to Eden - no hugelkultur. Fill beds with quality compost/soil, top with 4-6 inches wood chip mulch.

beds.name: Tomatoes
beds.description:
Dedicated tomato bed with basil companion. Tomatoes need **full sun**, **consistent water**, and **warm soil**.

### Layout
- **North end**: Indeterminate varieties (grow tallest)
- **South end**: Determinate/bush types
- **Interplanted**: Basil throughout (improves flavor, deters pests)

### Cautions
- Heavy feeders - amend soil generously
- Cage or stake **early** before roots establish
- Watch for: tomato hornworms, aphids, early blight
- **3-year rotation** - don't plant where nightshades grew recently
beds.notes: Cage or stake early. Heavy feeders - amend generously.

beds.name: Peppers & Eggplant
beds.description:
Nightshade companions that share similar growing needs. Both love heat and have similar pest profiles.

### Layout
- **Peppers**: 18" spacing, mix bell and hot varieties
- **Eggplant**: 24" spacing (larger plants)
- **Parsley**: Along edges as beneficial insect attractor

### Cautions
- Same family as tomatoes - rotate together on 3-year cycle
- Slower to establish than tomatoes
- Watch for: aphids, flea beetles
- Mulch heavily to retain moisture
beds.notes: Same family as tomatoes - rotate together.

beds.name: Summer Squash & Cucumbers
beds.description:
Fast-producing cucurbits that need frequent harvest. Dill is a classic cucumber companion.

### Layout
- **Zucchini/Yellow squash**: 1-2 plants each (very productive!)
- **Cucumbers**: Trellis or let sprawl
- **Dill**: Corners - attracts beneficial insects

### Cautions
- ⚠️ Harvest every 1-2 days or they get huge
- Vines **will** escape into paths
- Watch for: squash vine borers, cucumber beetles, powdery mildew
- **Drip irrigation only** - overhead water causes mildew
beds.notes: Harvest frequently. Vines will sprawl into paths.

beds.name: Winter Squash & Melons
beds.description:
Long-season crops that sprawl heavily. Plant and let them take over.

### Layout
- **Butternut/Spaghetti squash**: One plant each
- **Watermelon**: 1-2 plants (needs lots of space)
- **Tomatillo**: Corner - technically nightshade but sprawls like cucurbit

### Cautions
- ⚠️ Heavy sprawl - vines will go 10+ feet
- Long season (90-120 days) - plant early
- Hand-pollinate if bee activity is low
- Harvest when stem dries and skin hardens
beds.notes: Long season crops. Heavy sprawl - needs space.

beds.name: Salad Greens
beds.description:
Cool-season crops for continuous harvest. Succession plant for steady supply.

### Layout
- **Lettuce varieties**: Rows across bed
- **Arugula**: Fast-growing, plant every 2 weeks
- **Spinach**: Spring and fall (bolts in heat)

### Cautions
- ⚠️ **Bolt in heat** - provide afternoon shade in summer
- Succession plant every 2-3 weeks
- Cut-and-come-again harvest extends production
- Watch for: aphids, slugs
beds.notes: Succession plant every 2-3 weeks. Bolt in heat.

beds.name: Cooking Greens
beds.description:
Hardy greens that produce all season. More heat-tolerant than salad greens.

### Layout
- **Kale**: Center (gets large)
- **Collards**: 1-2 plants (very large)
- **Bok choy/Mustard**: Edges, faster crops
- **Swiss chard**: Colorful, harvest outer leaves

### Cautions
- Kale and collards can stay through light frost
- Watch for: cabbage worms, aphids
- Harvest outer leaves to extend production
- Bok choy bolts faster - plant for spring/fall
beds.notes: Hardy - can stay all season. Watch for cabbage worms.

beds.name: Legumes
beds.description:
Nitrogen-fixing crops that improve soil fertility. Great for rotation.

### Layout
- **Snap peas**: North end with trellis (4-5ft)
- **Bush beans**: Center rows, no support needed
- **Edamame**: South end, bushy plants

### Cautions
- ⚠️ **Keep AWAY from alliums** (bed-09) - they're antagonists
- Peas need trellis or support
- Beans are frost-sensitive - plant after last frost
- Inoculate seeds with rhizobium for best nitrogen fixation
beds.notes: Fix nitrogen in soil. Keep away from alliums. Peas need trellis.

beds.name: Root Vegetables
beds.description:
Underground crops that need deep, loose, rock-free soil. The 17" bed depth provides plenty of room.

### Layout
- **Carrots**: Center (need deepest soil)
- **Parsnips**: Next to carrots (similar needs, longer season)
- **Beets/Turnips**: Edges (shallower roots)
- **Radishes**: Interplant as quick crop

### Cautions
- Soil **must** be loose and rock-free for straight roots
- Thin ruthlessly - crowded roots fork
- Radishes ready in 25-30 days
- Parsnips need full season (100+ days)
beds.notes: Soil must be loose and rock-free. Thin ruthlessly.

beds.name: Alliums
beds.description:
Onion family crops with strong scent that deters many pests. Plant garlic in fall!

### Layout
- **Garlic**: Plant October-November, harvest July
- **Onions**: From sets in early spring
- **Scallions/Shallots**: Interplant as needed
- **Leeks**: Long season, start early

### Cautions
- ⚠️ **Keep AWAY from legumes** (bed-07) - alliums inhibit their growth
- Garlic needs cold period - plant before first frost
- Onions need consistent moisture for bulb development
- Watch for: onion maggots
beds.notes: Plant garlic in fall. Keep AWAY from legumes.

beds.name: Brassicas
beds.description:
Cole crops that prefer cool weather. Plant for spring and fall harvests.

### Layout
- **Broccoli**: 18-24" spacing
- **Cauliflower**: 24" spacing (needs room)
- **Cabbage**: 18" spacing
- **Brussels sprouts**: 24" (tall plants)

### Cautions
- Heavy feeders - amend soil well
- ⚠️ Watch for: cabbage worms, aphids, cabbage loopers
- Use row cover to prevent pest damage
- Brussels sprouts need longest season - plant early
beds.notes: Heavy feeders. Watch for cabbage worms and aphids.

beds.name: Potatoes & Herbs
beds.description:
Potatoes with herb companions. Chamomile improves potato flavor and health.

### Layout
- **Potatoes**: Most of bed, planted in trenches
- **Cilantro**: Edges (succession plant - bolts quickly)
- **Chamomile**: Corners (beneficial companion)
- **Stevia**: Corner (perennial in warmer zones)

### Cautions
- Hill potatoes 2-3 times as they grow
- ⚠️ **Don't plant where tomatoes/peppers grew** (same disease family)
- Harvest potatoes after vines die back completely
- Cilantro bolts fast - plant every 3 weeks
beds.notes: Hill potatoes 2-3 times as they grow. Don't plant where nightshades grew.

beds.name: Perennials
beds.description:
Permanent plantings that return yearly. **Do not disturb with annual tilling.**

### Layout
- **Asparagus**: One end (spreads via roots, needs dedicated space)
- **Rhubarb**: Corner (large plant, toxic leaves)
- **Herbs**: Clustered together (oregano, thyme, rosemary, sage, lavender)

### Cautions
- ⚠️ **DO NOT disturb** this bed with annual tilling
- Asparagus: 2-3 years to establish, then produces 15+ years
- Mediterranean herbs prefer **full sun, good drainage, low water**
- Rosemary may not survive Zone 6b winters - mulch heavily or pot up
beds.notes: DO NOT disturb annually. Asparagus takes 2-3 years to establish.

baseboard.purpose: Hardware cloth attachment point - cloth wraps around bottom edge and extends under entire enclosure

rodent.notes: Hardware cloth wraps around fence baseboard bottom edge, then extends across entire enclosure floor under mulch/paths
